Comments: I feel that this class expects too much of its instructor. While Dr Guymon does an excellent job of helping students learn to approach hard programming tasks  it often takes the time that would be of equal value spent teaching coding concepts. To make an analogy  this course focuses on teaching the complex grammar of a language before teaching any vocabulary. While possible  it feels out of order and is not very helpful. All the ''vocab'' or programming syntax  is not taught in class  but must be learned on one''s own. This is a waste of time  when you have an incredibly experienced programmer like Dr Guymon.

Comments: Course: I''d recomend looking at Physics 230 for a bit of inspiration: it''s a 1 credit online lab that wonderfuly directs students through learning mathematica (i took the classes simultaneously). It has CS110/111 as prereqs  even though its a fully different language. I feel like 263 could be streamlined *if and only if* the students had prior knowledge  wonderfuly built during the CS111 lectures. Have them take 111 one semester than a shrimple 1 credit online lab (maybe 1hr in person a week? recitation-style?) to walk them through the most important aspects of programing for ChemE. You could do 1 a semester  netting your a total of 14 major concepts  or 10 python and 4 excel  or any other permutation of pytyon  excel  and other tools. As is  263 feels like it itself is built against its students and the instructor for no reason other than "yeah idk ChemE is supposed to be hard  thus we won''t put in the work to make this easy  clear  or honestly useful".

Comments: This is only Dr. Guymon''s second year teaching  and as with any skill it takes time to learn. I was often left lost or confused after lectures and could only do the homework with the help of the TAs. It seems like maybe Dr. Guymon knows Python so well that he forgets that things that are intuitive to him are not intuitive to us. I felt like he often showed us things without explaining what they meant. Which is understandable and a weakness that I''ve seen even in much more experienced professors  but still frustrating.

Comments: The mini/weekly lab activities were mostly good. A few of them were pretty confusing  particularly the coding assignments where you were given code to alter and didn''t know what it was supposed to do. For those  maybe try teaching concepts a little more before throwing the code at us. The reactor cart was a good experience to work with systems of equipment and try new things. I know we were supposed to figure a lot of it out on our own  but it felt like we weren''t given direction or help. I understand wanting us to learn for ourselves  but we''ve never done a lab like this. It kind of felt like we were set up to fail.

Comments: Dr Guymon cares about good instruction  and I think he can improve in how he presents material. Often the way he teaches concepts is by writing on an iPad and then sharing the notes with us later. However  this was ineffective for me because the notes are difficult to follow - they are not easily legible or well organized. I much prefer the notes on the github site  because I know I''ll be able to read it and follow it. However  a lot of times I wished there were more detail in the notes. Alternatively  if the point is for us to take our own notes  I would still appreciate a more structured approach that facilitates my taking notes.

Comments: Dr. Guymon is understandably very busy with his various responsibilities. He usually sat in the corner of the lab working on projects or other work and was available for consulting as needed if students approached him  and he is very good at helping students seeking help. There was one time he was in the UO lab with us adding methocel into our non-newtonian fluid lab equipment where he took the time to explain in detail aspects of the labs parameters  history  and other aspects that were not in the lab write-up. There were some equipment and procedures he showed us too that went the extra mile to show us the context of process equipment and became a personal mentor for us for a few minutes. We really enjoyed that  and wished to see that effort for personal interaction and mentoring while completing our other labs rather than just fulfilling his supervisory and consulting roles as lab professor. It doesn''t need to be all the time  but if he joined groups and worked with them for a few minutes (or a half/whole lab) while making sure TAs were available to help the others (he can always step away as needed)  I think that would have enriched the experience significantly. Students could ask deeper questions  develop greater personal connections  and gain experience from his wisdom while he interacts with them. Dr. Guymon would also be able to see hands on a better perspective of how the labs actually run with users and be able to make tweaks to assignments (wording  format  procedures  order  help etc) that would otherwise be missed in high-level surveys near semester''s end.
wrapped:
Dr. Guymon is understandably very busy with his
various responsibilities. He usually sat in the
corner of the lab working on projects or other
work and was available for consulting as needed if
students approached him and he is very good at
helping students seeking help. There was one time
he was in the UO lab with us adding methocel into
our non-newtonian fluid lab equipment where he
took the time to explain in detail aspects of the
labs parameters history and other aspects that
were not in the lab write-up. There were some
equipment and procedures he showed us too that
went the extra mile to show us the context of
process equipment and became a personal mentor for
us for a few minutes. We really enjoyed that and
wished to see that effort for personal interaction
and mentoring while completing our other labs
rather than just fulfilling his supervisory and
consulting roles as lab professor. It doesn''t
need to be all the time but if he joined groups
and worked with them for a few minutes (or a
half/whole lab) while making sure TAs were
available to help the others (he can always step
away as needed) I think that would have enriched
the experience significantly. Students could ask
deeper questions develop greater personal
connections and gain experience from his wisdom
while he interacts with them. Dr. Guymon would
also be able to see hands on a better perspective
of how the labs actually run with users and be
able to make tweaks to assignments (wording
format procedures order help etc) that would
otherwise be missed in high-level surveys near
semester''s end.

Comments: Dr Guymon really cares about instruction and I think he can improve this skill. Often his instruction style was writing notes on an iPad during class and then sharing those notes. However  I found this difficult to follow during class and difficult to decipher afterwards. It was sometimes not easily legible and unorganized. I would have preferred typed notes that we annotate during class  or notes formatted similarly to the github site (latex is always legible). Alternatively  if the point is for us to take notes on our own  I feel the instruction could be formatted in a more linear  organized fashion to allow us to take notes. In my experience  having an excellent textbook and working problems from it helps my learning more than almost anything else. Lecture is sometimes difficult for me to focus  but if I can go over the concepts by reading them in the textbook (or even prepare by reading before class) and then work problems  the concepts are cemented far more firmly in my brain. Unfortunately  I did not like the textbook we used in this class. I felt it was dense and didn''t explain math very well. I also appreciate when textbooks give answers to at least odd questions so I can check them myself. I often don''t go back to look at answer keys for homework that instructors create  but if the answers are in the back of the book  I will check every problem. I''m not sure if a better book exists for this class  but just in general a good textbook is indispensable for me because it allows me to review concepts outside of lecture.

Comments: I never knew what to expect in this class. Things were always changing. It did get a little bit better towards the end of the semester  but not much. Quizzes due before class at 8 am were not created or posted until 7 pm the night before. We never knew when we would have homework assignments. They would just randomly show up on learning suit to be due in 2  maybe 3 days but were never mentioned in class. Or a homework assignment would be posted but then updated or changed a day later without sending an email or announcing in class that the homework assignment had to be changed. It was also hard to get help on finishing the homework because a lot of the time the TAs were not given homework solutions and they didn''t learn this content when they took the class. The course website was well organized with each lecture being a different section.

Comments: The organization of the class was really really confusing. I felt like topics didn''t connect to each other and I didn''t understand why we were learning about things that didn''t seem at all relevant to the class. For example  I felt like trying to teach us about choked flow and heat and mass transfer outside of the realm of the classes that teach those was a poor choice; there were so many things that we probably should have focused on that are integral to safety and the environment (ie. all the methods for remediation  something we barely even talked about)  but instead we spent a ton of time using transient balances  choked flow  heat and energy balances  and other things that were useful but didn''t seem like they were part of the core curriculum. It felt a lot like teaching advanced calculus in an introductory physics class; will it be useful  yes  but it isn''t what people are meant to be learning at that time.

Comments: This is probably the most painful portion of the entire course. He mentioned that he did not have time to work on entirety of the course structure  and it showed extensively. It almost felt as if there was no structure to any aspect of the class. Lecture topics did not line up with the homework assignments at all in most situations. There was also a scenario where there were test questions given on topics that were only lectured on in the weeks following the exam. Nothing was done to make up for this mistake either  even though it was mentioned that the question was a mistake  this also happened on the homework where it was mentioned after the fact that a certain question was not supposed to be on the homework  but nothing was done to remedy the mistake. This would not have been a serious issue if those particular homeworks did not take several hours to complete.

Comments: At times it felt somewhat disorganized. This may have been due to having to create content as he taught which I understand can''t be done all at once and was done well overall. The PHA and environmental sections were great. I wish there was more time in class dedicated to working on the math associated with PSI. Explaining the conceptual elements of the math and going over an example problem could help to alleviate some of the confusion. But if I didn''t understand in class I could always go to office hours or the TAs. I really enjoyed the presentations and projects. I feel like this really hit home the importance of safety in the workplace.

Comments: I really liked how professor Guymon obviously cared about trying to do everything to help us as students. He would share personal stories and have great spiritual thoughts. He listened and adapted to our midcourse feedback and made changes to the structure of the class accordingly. For example  many students asked for more example problems so professor Guymon changed the lectures to always go over examples. My only big complaint surrounding the class is that exam problems were sometimes seemed to be a completely different type of question surrounding a topic than what we did prior. I understand the importance of this to actually be able to apply understandings in a new way  but I would get frustrated seeing some of the problems on the exams because I thought that I was going in prepared just to find out I wasn''t. My next complaint is just about the course. It felt like there were too many topics that had to be covered that were very different from each other. Every day just felt like another big topic. It seemed like the course overall just had too many big and small topics that are all important enough to be mentioned  but this made it extremely difficult to fully understand topics as well as understand which topics would likely show up on exams.

Comments: We all had to write book reviews  and instead of grading them  Dr. Guymon had AI grade them. Comments: A clearer structure of the course would be helpful in planning out my semester from the beginning. Class notes provided through Freeform pdf''s are sometimes challenging to understand  especially when they contain necessary information that is not provided in the course website. When reviewing before a test or compiling study sheets  the handwriting can sometimes be hard to discern or be spontaneous. It will make sense while seeing it written during class  but often some things are just written down on the pdf with not much explanation or indication as to what it is referring to or what it means  making it confusing when looking back on it at a later date.

Comments: Dr Guymon is a stand-up guy. I appreciated his desire for us to succeed not just academically  but spiritually and as people. He really does care about our whole person. I also want to encourage Dr Guymon to continue working to inspire his students. Don''t let apathy or complaining get you down; students have always complained and always will. For this course specifically  it was difficult to get excited about the topics  which may be true for other students. If you can try to make the topics exciting and relevant  I think this would have an effect on student engagement.

Comments: This course was often times quite frustrating. The quizzes were random feeling but kind of got figured out by the end of the semester. The homeworks were DEFINITELY random feeling and didn''t always feel relevant to the material. I think it is a major downfall to include questions in homeworks that have not been covered in class and even worse including the mass balance question on the first midterm and then lecturing about it later. Huge problem for me and resulted in bitter feelings for sure. The course website is good but I feel like it misses the mark a little. I would probably prefer slides just for familiarity''s sake. I will be hesitant taking classes from Dr. Guymon in the future. I hope people aren''t being too mean in their reviews.

Comments: Clearly I''m not the instructor  but there were some aspects of the class that I didn''t agree with. Frankly I felt like we were underappreciated as students. Most of the class was ok but there were some things I wasn''t really a fan of.

Comments: I''m not sure if this is possible because of ABET  but I would suggest dissolving this 3 credit hour class. Instead of only talking about safety in safety class  let''s talk about safety issues in every class. When it''s time to talk about pumps in fluids  let''s talk about cavitation. Or why not incorporate LFL/UFL and PEL/IDLH  etc. in 273 when talking about transient balances? Instead of a 3-hour class  make a 1 credit seminar class for process hazards analysis and any other random tools that wouldn''t fall under the umbrella of other classes. I disliked the way that Dr. Guymon threw our book reports into an AI to give "feedback" then gave us all the same grade  then bragged about "grading" on LinkedIn. I don''t think that was fair to not tell us ahead of time that we would all be given the same grade. I really pushed myself to turn it in early because of the hard deadline that was imposed during a weekend I had planned to go out of town. In the end my grade on the assignment doesn''t matter  but I wish that we would have known the grading scheme ahead of time  otherwise I wouldn''t have spent as much energy on the project. The scope and length of the group project case study was great. The first exam was too long. The second exam was better  but still long. The resources for the 2nd test were better. There was too much reading for the class. Just have us read the relevant sections; there''s a lot we didn''t use or didn''t need to understand to get the important stuff. Please release assignments ahead of time! I disliked the way that Dr. Guymon asked for applause for small things that he has did. It seemed like sometimes he spent his time on elements that lasted 5 seconds of amusement in class instead of on elements that would have contributed to the organization of the course.

Comments: I think that Dr. Guymon was a very kind individual  but I believe that his approach to this class throughout the semester has been in overall failure. I have never been in a class where I''m never sure about what I should expect from my upcoming assignments. The overall experience ended up being not so bad  but it was still very difficult to feel like things would work out eventually  it just sort of happened that way. I definitely did not feel like I was going to do as well as i did in the class because of how difficult things were shaping up to be based on the classes terrible structure and organization. I think that eventually Dr. Guymon will be a great professor  but currently he is not there.

Comments: Dr. Guymon is a great guy spiritually and as someone to learn from  I was forced to learn a lot  but for this class often he went beyond the mark. The content and material of the class was great but the class structure needs a lot of work. Some exam content was not on safety or ethics or completely did not prepare students for. Python emphasis hurts this class because Excel  C+ are emphasized in other required classes. Project and assignment valve and points are changed after we submit them which makes it difficult to plan. Late uploads of assignments and homework make it impossible to plan around. TA''s answers typically involve "we never did this when I did the class" or need a key to answer students questions. Grading on assignments take upwards of a month which makes it impossible to know how you can change from the homework to do better on the exam. I''ll want to implore that Guymon is a great man and I''ve enjoyed every one-on-one interaction with him. It felt like he was thrown into a class with no structure. The class got better as time went on.

Comments: Professor Guymon may be one of the best professors I will have at BYU. I have really enjoyed having him for multiple different classes. This has help with continuity of teaching style. It is easy to tell that he cares a lot about the subject material and his students. I wish I could have him for every class going forward. I do think he teaches more material than the class''s curriculum necessitates  which is a double edged sword. I think this will prepare me well for a career  but it causes more stress during the class. I would give Professor Guymon a 10/10. He is very willing to adapt to accommodate students needs and change his teaching style based on student evaluation.

Topic: Question: Hours spent out of class
Comments: It depended on the lab. For the bioreactor lab  my team was putting in 12+ hours each week outside of the 6 scheduled hours for the lab. The cat meth lab was easily completed during class and only required maybe 1-2 hours outside of class. The PBL probably required about 3  since group of teams had one day less than the other group because of the schedule  which ended up with us having to rush a lot and stay afterwards to finish building things  coding in LabView  and putting together the documents required for the lab. I think the bioreactor lab needs to be either redesigned or simplified if possible. Everyone who did it had to invest a lot of time into setting things up and collecting data. It was to the point where we far exceeded the expectation of only spending 25 hours total on a lab. This definitely wasn''t Dr. Guymon''s fault though  as I think a group of people designed the bioreactor lab. But it does need some revision.

Comments: I have thoroughly enjoyed working with you and getting to know you this semester. As a side note  a couple of us noticed that the grade scale was changed near the end of the semester so you needed a 98% to earn an A in this class. I imagine this was done to fit within the regulations set by the department about this class. I just wish this would have been brought to our attention and discussed with us. It feels a little under the table to change this without bringing it forward. It would also be helpful to include your grade scale in your syllabus.

Comments: Dr Guymon really cares about his students. You can tell that he cares about us as individuals and he wants us to learn. I loved how he focused on helping us tie together many different concepts that we’ve learned throughout the program. He went out of his way to do demos and quizzes that would make us think and stretch us to remember and apply things we’ve learned in other classes. One way to make the quizzes better is to show the answers more clearly right after the quiz  so we can see what we did wrong. I also loved how Dr Guymon expected us to solve problems and figure things out  which helps us become better engineers  but he is also always willing to offer help.

Comments: The organization on canvas a scheduling was a bit spotty. It was kind of hard to figure out where answer keys and office hours were (once they were pointed out I could find them though). Towards the beginning/middle of the semester there would be homework assigned after class  but it wouldn''t be posted until the next day. Or he would change something in the homework a day after we started it  but didn''t tell us he modified the assignment (so anyone who already downloaded it didn''t know there were updated instructions). This did get a bit better as the semester progressed.

Comments: I thought that the assignments that Dr Guymon gave were challenging and helped us learn things on our own when we invested time into it. I thought that the earliest assignments were the best and most helpful  and then some of the later ones with solidworks or ansys were still good but not as good. I also think that for a lot of people it would have helpful to dive more deeply into python on a granular level and review basic concepts like lists  list slicing  dictionaries  name/variable management  frames/environments  etc. I think lots of people were tripped up on that while people with more coding experience struggled less.

Comments: Dr Guymon is seriously so invested in his students and helping them learn  both concepts related to class content and just overall in teaching them to achieve the aims of a BYU education and come closer to Jesus Christ. I have full confidence that he will only continue to become better and better at teaching and doing everything that comes with being a professor  and that he will continue to have a strong positive influence on his students. As far as the course goes  I thought it was a really excellent opportunity to learn how to leverage the power of python and other computational tools. I hope that the department continues to refine it and help us develop an even firmer foundation in those skills. I think there are some things that could be done to focus more on the fundamentals and the inner workings of python; I understand that this isn''t a CS course but I believe it is really helpful to understand some of what is going on under the hood as far as frames  environments  variables etc. I also think it would be extremely valuable to have some instruction on how to structure projects and code. How do I integrate code with other documents? What are best practices for organizing code? How does one use Git? I know that there is limited time in the course  but I think it''s worth it to get foundational skills that help learn how to collaborate on code and have a better understanding of core concepts at the heart of a lot of coding.

Comments: This was the worst lab experience that I have participated in yet. The organization of the lab was awful. It didn''t make any sense for canvas to be used. It made things way more complicated and unnecessary. The reactions lab was set up incorrectly. We spent most of our time trying to trouble shoot problems that we didn''t have to account for in the lab. The amount of work that we had to put into this for a half credit lab was ridiculous. Having to turn in two separate labs  yet one person turning both of them in makes no sense either  and there was no good reason other than "this is the direction that we chose to go this semester."

Comments: It sometimes feels a little bit silly to have a final for classes like this... we already have finals on pretty much all of this material in all of our other classes  and it feels like this class is mostly meant to give us a real-life representation/real-life examples of how these processes and concepts apply. Most of what we learn is learned in other classes  and then we see the real-life application in this class. The final in a class like this isn''t usually too hard  but it is hard to understand why we need to have one in the labs.

Comments: I think something could change about this class. We don''t have the time to do a big huge lab every time. It''s tough to see how to learn from these experiences when there is so much fluff around everything. I think there could be changes to making the prelab due by a certain time so we actually know what''s going on when we start. Either that or make the labs simpler so we can get through everything and not get behind.

Comments: I liked how the prelab prepared us with the information we needed to do the lab analysis. The prelabs and lab reports were very clear which was great. The labs were simple but meaningful and helped me connect what I learned in thermo and heat and mass. It was very conceptual which helped a lot because our other classes are not usually very conceptual. Also  I liked learning about and then using statistics. We don''t use statistics in our other classes but it is important so this really helped me solidify those concepts and practice.

Comments:
The instructor really cares and is super awesome. I liked the stats quizzes because they were straightforward and I liked the engineering fundamentals because it felt nice to get credit for writing out those ideas  and it made me feel adequate at something. I didn''t like the fundamentals quizzes--they were too nebulous. I wish we''d done reviews like we did with stats  where we reviewed the equation/concepts the class before the quiz. It was hard to see the demos sometimes  I should have moved  but it was also really stressful sometimes to have the time limits when I can''t even remember what concept goes with the demo. I think a few more puzzle pieces provided in those would have been better; however grading on them was relatively merciful and adequate extra credit was provided. I wished the "rubric" function of learning suite was better utilized--at least sometimes our scores felt a little arbitrary and I''m sure the instructor had reasons I just wish I understood them better for some of the scores. I felt like it was frustrating to get marked down because we didn''t get the same values the instructor got or we didn''t get a number we were "supposed to  this is a lab... unless the instructor can repeat that experiment several times and always gets that answer, and our procedures are specified extremely specifically, it''s kind of strange to grade based off of what number we got. The instructor loves and cares for the students and loves the Savior and we can all feel that. We feel listened to by the instructor. He has empathy for us. He is very cool. Thank you.
W 2023	CH EN 479 (Section 002)	62711427966	Does a great job leading students to learn what they are supposed to know
W 2023	CH EN 479 (Section 002)	18638190376	Dr. Guymon is an excellent professor and has a lot to offer to the university. He deeply understands concepts, patiently works with students and helps answer questions without immediately giving the answer, and has a positive view on life/how chemical engineering relates to it. Specifically, Dr. Guymon did an excellent job in bringing in demos almost everyday to class that helped review key chemical engineering concepts. I can tell Dr. Guymon is new and is hesitant in taking authority" in being a professor. I would recommend a confidence boost. Just remember you have a lot to offer to this university  and you belong here. I think that will give you a good confidence boost that will help you excel in leading a classroom to learn about chemical engineering.

adequate at something. I didn''t like the

before the quiz. It was hard to see the demos

(Section 002) 18638190376 Dr. Guymon is an
excellent professor and has a lot to offer to the
university. He deeply understands concepts,
patiently works with students and helps answer
questions without immediately giving the answer,
and has a positive view on life/how chemical
engineering relates to it. Specifically, Dr.
Guymon did an excellent job in bringing in demos
almost everyday to class that helped review key
chemical engineering concepts. I can tell Dr.
Guymon is new and is hesitant in taking authority"
in being a professor. I would recommend a
confidence boost. Just remember you have a lot to
offer to this university and you belong here. I
think that will give you a good confidence boost
that will help you excel in leading a classroom to
learn about chemical engineering.
feedback:
W 2023 CH EN 479 :The instructor really cares and is super awesome.
I liked the stats quizzes because they were
straightforward and I liked the engineering
fundamentals because it felt nice to get credit
for writing out those ideas and it made me feel
adequate at something. I didn''t like the
fundamentals quizzes--they were too nebulous. I
wish we''d done reviews like we did with stats
where we reviewed the equation/concepts the class
before the quiz. It was hard to see the demos
sometimes I should have moved but it was also
really stressful sometimes to have the time limits
when I can''t even remember what concept goes with
the demo. I think a few more puzzle pieces
provided in those would have been better; however
grading on them was relatively merciful and
adequate extra credit was provided. I wished the
"rubric" function of learning suite was better
utilized--at least sometimes our scores felt a
little arbitrary and I''m sure the instructor had
reasons I just wish I understood them better for
some of the scores. I felt like it was frustrating
to get marked down because we didn''t get the same
values the instructor got or we didn''t get a
number we were "supposed to this is a lab...
unless the instructor can repeat that experiment
several times and always gets that answer, and our
procedures are specified extremely specifically,
it''s kind of strange to grade based off of what
number we got. The instructor loves and cares for
the students and loves the Savior and we can all
feel that. We feel listened to by the instructor.
He has empathy for us. He is very cool. Thank you.

Comments: I thoroughly enjoyed this class. I appreciated the spiritual thoughts  your sincerity and respect  and the physical demonstrations for the quizzes. I also appreciated all of the extra credit. I appreciated being able to come to class and show up  and not have to stress about getting every assignment absolutely perfect in order to get an A.

Comments: Yeah Dr. Guymon! You killed it in your first semester! Thank you for showing me how you calibrated the data for the CSTR labs. That was cool to see the behind-the-scenes. I loved the labs. It was fun to mess around with a real CSTR and PFR  as well as see material properties in action. I especially loved the corrosion labs  as it helped solidify corrosion principles in my head. I think a little bit more explanation on the pressure relief valve lab would be great. On question 3 of Lab 9  there was a question about finding the time it takes for the pressure relief valve to close. There were so many equations in the tank blowdown math packet that we got lost and didn''t know which ones to use. It took a lot of TA help  and even then  it was hard to know what to do. Some more explanation would be good! Other than that  the labs were fair and exciting. I enjoyed them all. This class was a fun one to come to.
wrapped:
Yeah Dr. Guymon! You killed it in your first
semester! Thank you for showing me how you
calibrated the data for the CSTR labs. That was
cool to see the behind-the-scenes. I loved the
labs. It was fun to mess around with a real CSTR
and PFR as well as see material properties in
action. I especially loved the corrosion labs as
it helped solidify corrosion principles in my
head. I think a little bit more explanation on the
pressure relief valve lab would be great. On
question 3 of Lab 9 there was a question about
finding the time it takes for the pressure relief
valve to close. There were so many equations in
the tank blowdown math packet that we got lost and
didn''t know which ones to use. It took a lot of
TA help and even then it was hard to know what
to do. Some more explanation would be good! Other
than that the labs were fair and exciting. I
enjoyed them all. This class was a fun one to come
to.
feedback:
F 2022 CH EN 345 :Yeah Dr. Guymon! You killed it in your first
semester! Thank you for showing me how you
calibrated the data for the CSTR labs. That was
cool to see the behind-the-scenes. I loved the
labs. It was fun to mess around with a real CSTR
and PFR as well as see material properties in
action. I especially loved the corrosion labs as
it helped solidify corrosion principles in my
head. I think a little bit more explanation on the
pressure relief valve lab would be great. On
question 3 of Lab 9 there was a question about
finding the time it takes for the pressure relief
valve to close. There were so many equations in
the tank blowdown math packet that we got lost and
didn''t know which ones to use. It took a lot of
TA help and even then it was hard to know what
to do. Some more explanation would be good! Other
than that the labs were fair and exciting. I
enjoyed them all. This class was a fun one to come
to.
